subNodes.conversationText: root

Greetings.  I am Oudin Asterchord, proprietor.  You are adventurers, I take it.  A pleasing sight for a dealer in antiquarian objects.||***ga_jump-->String::aster_vromanwp    String::vroman    Float::0    ***gc_comp_remove-->NOT::True    String::gossam    ***gc_journal_entry-->NOT::True    String::Q_MANFRED    String::85    ||
And, because Ianth Lavillus walks with you, you must be adventurers of a good sort.||***ga_jump-->String::aster_ianthwp String::ianth Float::0 ***gc_comp_remove-->NOT::False String::ianth ||
Your logic flatters me, Oudin.
Nay, Ianth, it is your presence that flatters me. I am the only one in Drawn Swords to realize how much you honor the town by being here, so I do not think my courtesy too extravagant.
So, what can I do for you on this fine autumn <day/night>?
Let me see what you have to sell.

Of course! [Whispering.] My nephew Gossam, over by the window, is an adventurer himself. He is a cleric of Sheela Peryroyl, and might be interested in joining your party. Just a thought. [Oudin stops whispering--]|***gc_journal_entry-->NOT::True String::Q_GREEN String::!0 |
Remember that I will also pay well to buy certain items.
[Examine Oudin's wares.]|***ga_open_store-->String::asterchord_store Int::0 Int::0 |
Tell me about yourself, Oudin.

Ah.  A most delightful subject.  I jest, of course.  I am merely an old shopkeeper and amateur collector and historian.  I grew up in Gullykin, on the Sword Coast, but spent most of my adult life in Beregost.
How did you end up in Drawn Swords?

Danmar, the innkeeper, used to be something of an adventurer, and he and I often met in Feldepost's Inn in Beregost.  After he took over the Sword and Dragon, he invited me to open up a shop in Drawn Swords, generously splitting the cost of building with me.
Interesting.  Farewell.
[Gesturing at the books and odds and ends strewn about.] So you are a shopkeeper and a scholar, I take it.
Yes.  In fact, if you are going to be adventuring in the area, you ought to come to me if you have any questions about local history.  The Backlands have much lore, but little of it is known.
Where did you acquire all of these treasures?

Some of it comes from trading with adventurers when I lived in Beregost.  A good deal of my trove, though, comes from an auction that was held near Daggerford when a famous antiquarian named Torleth Mindulspeer passed away.  I purchased some of my best items from his estate.
I do not need anything at the moment.  Farewell.

[Sleight of Hand] The items you have in this store are quite fascinating...[As you speak, pocket a small brooch you notice on Asterchord's table.]|***gc_check_class-->NOT::False Int::1 ***gc_check_class-->NOT::False Int::8 |

[Success] [You pocket the brooch swiftly.] Yes, the years have been kind to this old collector.||***ga_give_item-->String::mi_coralbrooch Int::1 Int::0 ***ga_give_xp-->Int::200 Int::0 ***gc_skill_dc-->NOT::False Int::21 Int::18 ||

[Failure] [You drop the brooch!] Yes, the years have been kind to this old collector. Oh my! That brooch that just fell on the flloor is one of my most valuable non-magical items--give it here, please--such things are too easily lost among the mess I have in here.
Hello!  If you need anything, let me know.||***ga_jump-->String::aster_vromanwp    String::vroman    Float::0    ***gc_journal_entry-->NOT::True    String::Q_MANFRED    String::>70    ||
Oudin, perhaps you would know something about a door I found in the Swordskeep Crypt...[Tell the shopkeeper about the door and the poem.] |***gc_journal_entry-->NOT::False String::Q_LUDOS String::1 |
Interesting indeed!  That is a stanza from an anonymous old poem called "The Falcon and the Dove."|***ga_jump-->String::aster_ianthwp    String::ianth    Float::0    |

The door, on the other hand, probably leads to the tomb of Ludos, the robber-knight who built Swordskeep.  If, as you say, it was hidden, it was probably overlooked by the Bairnsons when they renovated the keep--and has remained overlooked until now.
What the door and the inscription have to do with each other is a mystery to me, although Vroman is probably right that figuring out the connection would get you into the tomb.
What else can you tell me about the poem?
Well, "The Falcon and the Dove" is a poem about unrequited love, for one thing.  What else?  It's tragic--the poet's beloved dies at a place called Castle Joyous--and, oh!--
[Suddenly bristling with excitement.] Why of course! The castle! That must be it!
Do you have any idea what the connection could be?

<color=green>[Bard/Lore] I know "The Falcon and the Dove," that it's a love poem, and that the poet's beloved loses her life at a mythical place called Castle Joyous.  Do you know anything else about it?|***gc_skill_dc-->NOT::False    Int::13    Int::22    ***gc_check_class-->NOT::False    Int::1    |
[Suddenly bristling with excitement.] Why of course! The castle! That must be it!|***ga_give_xp-->Int::100 Int::0 |
I happen to know that the castle where the poem takes place is not a myth, as many believe, and that it lies a day's march from Drawn Swords. I know very little about it otherwise, though.
Ah.  Then perhaps our answers lie there.

Perhaps they do.  You are lucky--I am one of the few that have a map of this area old enough to pinpoint its location for you, though I must warn you that some of the monsters of the Backlands have probably claimed it.

I have no idea how Ludos could be connected to Castle Joyous or this poem.  He was, by all accounts, a cruel and vicious man, and eventually starved to death in Swordskeep because he had no subjects loyal enough to stay over winter with him.

I believe that the clergy of Helm entombed him.  Perhaps it was merely a fancy of theirs to seal him in with an inscrutable poem rather than a key.  But if there are answers to be had, Castle Joyous seems like the best place to start.
Then perhaps we shall have to go investigate this "Castle Joyous" ourselves.
What do the rest of you think?  Should we investigate this Castle Joyous?
I appreciate your asking.  |***ga_global_int-->String::ianth_inf    String::++    |
As you know, I was initially apprehensive about tomb-raiding, but I have to confess that the mystery intrigues me. We do have much to do already, though.

You should know by now that I go where you follow, . I trust you implicitly, you know? [Ironically.] I am a little more suspicious of the gold with which our adventures have lined my pockets, but I'm learning to trust it.

I would disappoint Uncle Asterchord greatly if I disagreed. Besides, I'm curious too--and if this "Castle Joyous" is as beautiful as the poem suggests, it will be a picturesque little jaunt.|***gc_comp_remove-->NOT::False String::gossam |
If you decide to pursue this, , I wish you all the best. And don't forget to tell me what you find out--or to sell me what you find. I am most curious myself.
Thank you, Oudin.  Farewell!|***ga_journal-->String::Q_LUDOS    Int::5    Int::0    Int::0    Int::0    ***ga_global_int-->String::castlej_map    String::1    |
[Nod goodbye.]|***ga_journal-->String::Q_LUDOS Int::5 Int::0 Int::0 Int::0 ***ga_global_int-->String::castlej_map String::1 |
[Nod.] I'll think about this.
What could this have to do with Ludos the robber-knight or his tomb?

I have no idea how Ludos could be connected to Castle Joyous or this poem.  He was, by all accounts, a cruel and vicious man, and eventually starved to death in Swordskeep because he had no subjects loyal enough to stay over winter with him.

I believe that the clergy of Helm entombed him.  Perhaps it was merely a fancy of theirs to seal him in with an inscrutable poem rather than a key.  But if there are answers to be had, Castle Joyous seems like the best place to start.
You are lucky--I am one of the few that have a map of this area old enough to pinpoint its location for you, though I must warn you that the monsters of the Backlands have probably staked it out.
Oudin, I thought you'd like to know that we solved the mystery of Castle Joyous...[Tell Oudin about your adventures.]|***gc_journal_entry-->NOT::False String::Q_LUDOS String::30 |
My, that's truly extraordinary!  Ludos the robber-knight was author of "The Falcon and the Dove," and his beloved a regal song dragon!  Splendid!|***ga_fade_from_black-->Float::4    |
It is certainly exciting to have adventurers such as yourselves around. If I am a lorekeeper, you are a loregiver.

Greetings.  I wanted to extend my thanks to you personally, <FirstName>, for all you have done and continue to do for Drawn Swords.  Poor Anselm!|***gc_journal_entry-->NOT::True    String::Q_MANFRED    String::85    |
Thank you, Oudin.
What can I do for you today?
But of course.
Hello again.  The air is getting chilly, isn't it?  Winter approaches.|***gc_journal_entry-->NOT::True    String::Q_MANFRED    String::85    |
Hamfast has told me to lock up, and I will very soon, but I thought I might see the group of you before I did.|***gc_journal_entry-->NOT::False    String::Q_MANFRED    String::85    |

I am glad you did, Uncle Asterchord.  This might be the last time we see each other in some time--we are on our way to the Flame Stone, and after that--who knows?  I will probably head back to Corm Orp.|***gc_comp_remove-->NOT::False    String::gossam    |

Then I am indeed glad you stopped in to see me. Farewell, my nephew. And do take care. Hamfast did not tell me much...but what with Danmar gone, and Hamfast's nervous silence, I can guess that there's some mischief in the air.
In any case...
